title: NISAR (satellite)
text:
The NASA-ISRO Synthetic Aperture Radar (NISAR) mission is a joint project between <a href="NASA">NASA</a> and <a href="ISRO">ISRO</a> to co-develop and launch a dual-frequency <a href="synthetic%20aperture%20radar">synthetic aperture radar</a> on an <a href="Earth%20observation%20satellite">Earth observation satellite</a>. The satellite will be the first <a href="radar%20imaging">radar imaging</a> satellite to use dual frequencies. It will be used for <a href="remote%20sensing">remote sensing</a>, to observe and understand natural processes on <a href="Earth">Earth</a>. For example, its left-facing instruments will study the <a href="Antarctica">Antarctic</a> <a href="cryosphere">cryosphere</a>. With a total cost estimated at US$1.5 billion, NISAR is likely to be the world's most expensive Earth-imaging satellite.
Overview.
The NASA-ISRO <a href="Synthetic-aperture%20radar">Synthetic Aperture Radar</a>, or NISAR satellite, will use advanced radar imaging to map the elevation of Earth's land and ice masses 4 to 6 times a month at resolutions of 5 to 10 meters. It is designed to observe and measure some of the planet's most complex natural processes, including <a href="Disturbance%20%28ecology%29">ecosystem disturbances</a>, <a href="Ice-sheet%20dynamics">ice-sheet collapse</a>, and natural hazards such as <a href="earthquake">earthquake</a>s, <a href="tsunami">tsunami</a>s, <a href="volcano">volcano</a>es and <a href="landslide">landslide</a>s.
Under the terms of the agreement, NASA will provide the mission's <a href="L%20band">L-band</a> <a href="Synthetic-aperture%20radar">synthetic aperture radar</a> (SAR), a high-rate telecommunication subsystem for scientific data <a href="Satellite%20navigation%20device">GPS receivers</a>, a solid-state recorder, and a payload data subsystem. ISRO will provide the <a href="satellite%20bus">satellite bus</a>, an <a href="S%20band">S-band</a> synthetic aperture radar, the launch vehicle, and associated launch services.
All data from NISAR would be freely available 1 to 2 days after observation and within hours in case of emergencies like natural disasters. Data collected from NISAR will reveal information about the evolution and state of <a href="Crust%20%28geology%29">Earth's crust</a>, help scientists better understand our planet's natural processes and <a href="Climate%20change">changing climate</a>, and aid future resource and hazard management. The mission is a partnership between <a href="NASA">NASA</a> and <a href="ISRO">ISRO</a>.
The satellite will be <a href="Attitude%20control">three-axis stabilized</a>. It will use a deployable mesh antenna and will operate on both the <a href="L%20band">L-</a> and <a href="S%20band">S-</a> microwave bands. The aperture mesh reflector (antenna) will be supplied by Astro Aerospace, a <a href="Northrop%20Grumman">Northrop Grumman</a> company.
The satellite will be launched from India aboard a <a href="Geosynchronous%20Satellite%20Launch%20Vehicle">GSLV Mk II</a> on 29 January 2023. The orbit will be a <a href="Sun-synchronous%20orbit">Sun-synchronous</a>, dawn-to-dusk type. The planned mission life is three years. The project has passed the first stage of the design validation phase and has been reviewed and approved by NASA.
ISRO's share of the project cost is about , and NASA's share is about US$808 million.
